Key Arguments: The definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the Bill are ambiguous and open to subjective interpretation.
The Bill poses a threat to freedom of speech by giving ACMA the power to enforce codes of practice and industry standards, which could suppress differing views and stifle healthy debate.
The legislation seems to target social media, potentially leading to a one-size-fits-all approach that does not account for diverse views.
There is a concern that the Bill could lead to censorship and centralization of power, limiting open debate and the development of critical skills.
The submission references past instances where information labeled as misinformation was later revealed to be true, questioning the reliability of centralized control over information.
Notable Quotes: Definitions of the terms misinformation and disinformation are ambiguous.

Threats to Freedom of Speech. Giving the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) the power to enforce codes of practice and industry standards risks the suppressing of differing views and stifles healthy debate.
It is the stifling of human debate that concerns me the most: this seems to be an attempt to control human beings’ rights to share views openly.
Such a Bill has censorship inherent in it – a direct attack on our freedom and enhances the centralisation of power into the hands of a few.
